title: Tom Brady signs massive $375 million contract to broadcast NFL games when he retires, report says; Brady says he is excited to be an analyst but at the same time has 'unfinished business' on the football field
text:
The New York Post reportedthat Brady had reached a deal with Fox on a 10-year contract worth up to $375 million, the largest contract in sportscasting history. Brady made about $293 million playing quarterback in the NFL for 22 seasons, the most of any football player in history, and even that is still lower than his broadcasting contract.

Brady confirmed the news with a Tuesday morning tweet, saying he still has "unfinished business" on the football field.

When the 44-year-old actually retires is still an open question. Brady retired in February only to reverse his decision and opt to play in the upcoming 2022 season with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. While Brady, set to turn 45 in August, doesn't have a contract beyond 2022, he has publicly stated that he could play in the NFL at a more advanced age. "I do think I could play till 50," Brady told Complex earlier this year.

Contracts for NFL TV analysts have exploded in recent years, with Walt Disney DIS unit ESPN signing Troy Aikman to a reported five-year, $90 million contract, and Joe Buck inking a five-year deal for $75 million.

Brady is set to be paid $15 million by the Bucaneers this year, according to contract data from Spotrac, and he has amassed a $475 million fortune during his career.
